Evaluation: This part of the ontology deals with the assessment of the idea in its finalized form. It includes the impact created, the value added, and the outcomes achieved.5. Improvement: Based on the feedback, this part explores how the idea can be further improved, expanded, or optimized.Relationships can be established among different parts of the ontology. For example, an idea has a development process, an implemented idea is subject to evaluation, and the evaluation leads to feedback, which, in turn, leads to improvements. The ontology also could incorporate sub-concepts such as:a. Original Idea: This would include whether the idea is novel or has been inspired /built upon previous ideas.  b. Potential: Representing the projected or estimated success, impact, and effectiveness of the idea. c. Context: This will hold information about the circumstances, environment or situation that may affect or has led to the creation of the idea. d. Impact:   - Range of Influence: The capacity or power of an idea to be a compelling force on or produce effects on the actions, behavior, opinions, etc., of a person or group.6. Idea Relations:   - Derived Ideas: Ideas that are developed based on or as a development from an existing idea.      - Related Ideas: Ideas that are associated with or connected to other ideas, though not necessarily from one another.      - Contradictory Ideas: Ideas that are in conflict or disagreement with each other.7.
